q: What are the symptoms of a stomach ulcer?
i: Some people may experience other symptoms, such as indigestion, heartburn and acid reflux and feeling sick.
a: The most common symptoms of a stomach ulcer are a burning or gnawing pain in the centre of the tummy (abdomen), indigestion, heartburn, acid reflux, and feeling sick.

q: When should I seek medical advice for a stomach ulcer?
a: You should visit your GP if you think you may have a stomach ulcer. Contact your GP or NHS 111 immediately if you are passing dark, sticky, tar-like stools or if you have a sudden, sharp pain in your tummy that gets steadily worse. Go to your nearest accident and emergency (A&E) department or call 999 if you are vomiting blood.

q: What can cause stomach ulcers?
a: Stomach ulcers can be caused by an infection with Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) bacteria or taking anti-inflammatory medicines (NSAIDs), such as ibuprofen or aspirin. It used to be thought that stress or certain foods might cause stomach ulcers, but there's little evidence to suggest this is the case.

q: How are stomach ulcers treated?
a: Treatment for stomach ulcers depends on the underlying cause. Most people will be prescribed a medication called a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) to reduce the amount of acid in their stomach. Antibiotics may also be prescribed if the ulcers were caused by a H. pylori infection.

q: Do stomach ulcers have any complications?
a: Complications of stomach ulcers, though relatively uncommon, can be serious and potentially life-threatening. They include bleeding at the site of the ulcer, the splitting open of the stomach lining at the site of the ulcer (perforation), and the ulcer blocking the movement of food through the digestive system (gastric obstruction).

q: Who is more likely to get stomach ulcers?
a: Stomach ulcers can affect anyone but are more common in people aged 60 or over. Men are more affected than women.

q: What are the signs and symptoms of a stomach ulcer?
a: The most common symptom of a stomach ulcer is a burning or gnawing pain in the centre of the tummy (abdomen). Other symptoms may include indigestion, heartburn, acid reflux, and feeling sick.

q: What should I do if I see blood in my vomit?
a: If you are vomiting blood, which can appear bright red or have a dark brown, grainy appearance similar to coffee grounds, you should go to your nearest accident and emergency (A&E) department or call 999 as this could be a sign of a serious complication, such as internal bleeding.

q: Can stomach ulcers come back after treatment?
a: Stomach ulcers can come back after treatment, although this is less likely to happen if the underlying cause is addressed.

q: What are the possible complications of stomach ulcers?
a: Possible complications of stomach ulcers include bleeding at the site of the ulcer, the stomach lining at the site of the ulcer splitting open (perforation), and the ulcer blocking the movement of food through the digestive system (gastric obstruction).
